newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: ECNZ revaluation lifts assets $655 million.
newsitem.headline: ECNZ revaluation lifts assets $655 million.

text.p: NZ government-owned electricity generator Electricity Corp of New Zealand said on Thursday it had revalued its assets by NZ$655 million to $3.3 billion.
The likelihood of a revaluation was made public by Moody's Investor Service on Wednesday, but was not due to be released by the company until its annual report in October.
ECNZ media relations manager Karen Jones confirmed the level of revaluation.
Moody's said it was concerned at the the New Zealand government's aggressive financial management of ECNZ.
But Finance Minister Bill Birch told Reuters he did not think the government was "any more aggressive with ECNZ than state owned enterprises generally".
"Our policy is to work with the commercial board to develop a dividend policy. But that is not inflexible. If they make a good case to retain earnings the government takes that into account."
Birch said he had no comment to make on a likely special dividend from ECNZ forecast by Moody's.

He said the ratio of 40 percent debt to total capitalisation mentioned as likely by Moody's "we regard as a benchmark across the state owned enterprises and Crown-owned entities, but it is not inviolate."
"But we don't encourage Crown companies to build up cash reserves without good reason."
Asked if there would be a similar revaluation of Contact Energy, split from ECNZ in February, Birch said "we will wait and see".
He said "valuations were going in all directions" and pointed to the downward revision of Forestry Corporation's assets prior to its sale.

Contact Energy's media relations manager Bruce Thompson confirmed the company was revaluing its assets, set at $1.693 billion in February, and said the results would be in the annual report for the year to September.
